Title: Last Ounce of Courage

reviewText: The Last Ounce of Courage, is a stylized story about a so-called US patriot named Revere, not the 18th century Boston silversmith  -- but a contemporary character, who, as an Army sergeant in Viet Nam risked his life in combat. As the story unfolds, the bitter and reclusive Revere becomes motivated to undertake  a new fight against America's "enemies within," and "reclaim freedoms that are being lost."TLOoC is a poorly structured, cliche-scripted and clumsily acted film. Most of the characters are types, not real characters, always the sign of a film gone awry. It does have a few touching moments such as when Revere Jr. enlists for the Iraq War of 1990 (I think - it is unclear which theatre he is stationed), leaves his family, and at the end, when the family comes together -- although the conclusion offers little surprises. TLOoC is in the genre of the Hallmark Hall of Fame family-friendly TV dramas, but with none of the latter's professionalism.Nevertheless, the far right wing has come out to endorse TLOoC, including the extremist James Dobson, founder of the American Family Association, and the NRA, who also support military style assault weapons with high capacity ammo clips, like those that riddled the bodies of school children at Newton, Connecticutt.The movie starts when Revere, Sr, who is signaled to the viewer as "an American hero," a Harley-Davidson riding veteran with colors, the archetype of white male freedom and individualism. In case you missed the point, he sports a huge American Flag waving behind his bike  and is at the center of the plot of TLOoC. In the standard patriotic mythology of the white far right wing, he served in Viet Nam where he won medals rescuing POWs - a Rambo variation -- though one mission went fatally bad and he is haunted by it. Revere Sr.  has a son who grows up, marries and enlists to fight the first Gulf War (I think), a call of duty that entails him leaving behind a new and pregnant wife. Revere Jr. is killed in an attack, and this somehow got videotaped. When the tape is returned to the family it is viewed and this stuns/grieves them, later calling them to action. Thereafter, the father and daughter-in-law  grow somewhat apart.Some years later, Revere Sr. connects with the family Revere Jr. left behind. Finding his grandson, he performs the right wing ritual of familial inheritance, sharing - a bit reluctantly - his prize possessions to the boy.  He gives his son's Gideon Bible (here a textual fundamentalist paladin like the Ark of the Convenant. Didn't anyone have an NIV?) that the grandson's father carried with him in Iraq.  The boy takes these items to school, where a twittish principal (a symbol of un-masculine secular authority - a familiar right wing caricature) is indignant that this "unacceptable text," was brought to school. He threatens suspension of the grandson but goes easy on him telling him to not violate the school's "Bible ban." After that, the plot thickens. (In the real world, there is nothing to prevent high schoolers from bringing their Bibles to school for their own use - but that doesn't matter to the writer of TLOoC.)Grandfather Revere, who is now the part-time mayor of the small town, learns about this incident and concludes a conspiracy is afoot to undermine our precious freedoms.  He recalls that the city cannot celebrate Christmas now with public displays of the Nativity and Christian crosses like they once used to display. He concludes that a small minority of "fanatics" stopped some 85% of "true American citizens" (a statistic cited via Fox News commentator Bill O' Reilly in the film) from observing Christmas, as if Nativity displays on public property are appropriate Christian worship. He becomes convinced that he fought a war for this right and now it is being "taken away" from him -- i.e. he "wants his country back." The annual Fox News "War on Christmas" get its own film and Revere re-names the town "Christmas City!"Revere Sr. then encounters an enemy (read, right wing scapegoat) against his efforts to set up Christmas decorations around the town: Fred Hammersmith, a militant ACLU type, and perhaps the most ineptly drawn figure in the film. All TLOoC needs is for on-screen prompts to boo him whenever he appears. Revere Sr. the mayor, also acquired a government grant to build a home for disabled veterans. However, Hammersmith and his liberal allies try to block the use of these funds because of the Revere's pro-Christmas actions. In a classic plot turn in the white fundamentalist nationalist myth of resurgence, our hero decides he has had enough. With stern resolve, and the help of his grandson, Revere Sr. hauls an illuminate cross in the vintage pickup that the deceased Revere Jr. was to inherit (a classic Salvation Army model - "Jesus Saves") and raises it on the highest place of a private town building -- an act of REVERE-ance? It was apparently removed when someone complained about it awhile back. Excuse me here, a cross on private property is no one's business. In an act of vigilantism -- and without the building owner's permission -- Revere Sr. & grandson install the illuminate cross on the face of the building. For his pains, the mayor is handcuffed, arrested and taken to jail, but not until having a bonding embrace with his grandson.Taking a page from the Book of Acts, an "angel"/"Christ" comforts/inspires the mayor in jail, preceding his release. This curious figure looks a little like a middle-age Jesus if Our Lord were a "silver fox" and favored country and western garb. Meanwhile the local school where the grandson was harassed is about to stage a "holiday play," using a non-Christian "New Age" theme. But, in a plot turn, the actor/students rebel and have garbed themselves in costumes from the characters in the Nativity story, beneath their "pagan" costumes. In vindictive triumph, they cast off their intended costumes and present the "true story" of Christmas, the Nativity Scene with recited Gospel text.  The angry principal storms onto the stage, scolding the students, but then sees that the audience has been moved by the Christmas play and ends up applauding it.What really galled me was the fusing of Christianity with American nationalism/patriotism (a heresy, by the way). The crowd stands and an American flag (here an object of worship) is brought out, blocking the baby Jesus in His manger!! A veteran in the crowd and all present stand to salute the flag. Someone screens Revere Jr's last video for the crowd and there isn't a dry eye in the house. This prompts the mayor/hero to declare that he will become a "freedom fighter" to combat the enemies who seek to undermine the traditions and freedom of the country he fought for.  In this emotional nationalist incident the salvation of America has begun in the town's resistance.In conclusion, TLOoC is a classic piece of white far right wing mythology -- with a predictable script and godawful acting. It is, however, an excellent example of the resentment the the white far right wing feels against a vague enemy in this period of transition. Go the website Rottentomatoes.com, a forum for film reviews. TLOoC did not get a single favorable review from professional critics.
Title: Last Ounce of Courage

reviewText: I wasn't sure what to expect from this movie, but it got my attention after seeing a few commercials for it. I found the story very moving. It covers loss, betrayal, forgiveness, rebirth, patriotism and pride. Year after we continue to see the attacks on religion and our freedoms and this movie captures that. I thought the acting was fine, but more importantly the message that is given. It was so nice to sit down and watch a movie that didn't have constant profanity,drug use, or the gratuitous sex scene that doesn't add to the movie. Bottom line...a very enjoyable movie that the entire family can watch. I'll add this to "my movies to watch at Christmas" list. Highly recommended.
Title: Last Ounce of Courage

reviewText: First, let's do full disclosure. I am a Republican, a conservative, and DO think that the left has a sincere desire to secularize the nation. There. I said it. Now...to the movie. It's overly dramatic, over written, and over acted. I HATE propaganda, no matter where it comes from, and (I'm sorry to say) this is propaganda. The long self-righteous monologues from the main character are so melodramatic and downright sappy that I was truly finding it difficult to keep watching. I find crap like this insulting because, as conservatives, WE DON'T NEED IT. We don't need to produce this kind of over-the-top garbage. This movie casts conservatives as the one thing we all despise and promised we would never be: Victims. That's right. This movie makes conservatives out to be a crying underclass being squished down by "the man", except in this case the man is a left-wing political activist. I want to fight for by believes but I am not going to do it by taking a page from the New Left playbook.
summary: I wanted to like this. I really did. But....
Title: Last Ounce of Courage

reviewText: What beliefs do you have? In what circumstances are you willing to stand for them? Are you willing to die for them? To go to jail for them? reviewText: This movie is all about standing up for what you believe in and challenges you at your very core to do what you know is right. It involves a father whose son goes off to war and dies for his country. Years later his grandson challenges him to stand up for what he believes in. Far too many movies have so much cursing and violence that I find that to be a turnoff. It doesn't seem filmakers can make a movie anymore without the f bomb in it every 5 seconds. This movie however is very refreshing and you will find yourself wanting to watch it over and over again. Even though there are very limited special features it still makes it an outstanding movie.

reviewText: Last Ounce of Courage sounds like a movie about military pride and patriotism, but I found it to be much more than that.  The storytelling/pacing is much better than a lot of Christian movies I've seen.  The movie contains components of family reconciliation, romance, politics, humor, and the supernatural.  The heart of the movie is religious freedom.  It is insane of the political left to interpret religious freedom as the freedom to practice, but not share, your religion.  This movie accurately shows the extent to which leftists fight against the public display of religion, as if it's the government's job to keep any religion from having a more important place than any other religion.  Religious freedom is severely under attack in America, and this movie is an enriching story of how citizens can fight for it.
summary: One of the best faith-based movies I've seen
Title: Last Ounce of Courage

reviewText: For too long we have let the idea of political correctness keep many of us from openly practicing what we believe.Christmas is no longer Christmas but rather holiday season.  Christmas trees are "holiday trees".  All because of the idea that sombody may be "offended" should you call a Christmas tree as Christmas tree.  This is a story of people who just get fed up with the PC BS and express their beliefs.  If I'm expected to tolerate your beliefs, then you sould tolerate mine.  I don't bother you when you express what you believe so leave me alone when I express what I believe in.  I'm not forcing you to attend my  celebration and I will not curtail it just because you don't like it.  This movie expresses some of these ideas.
Title: Last Ounce of Courage

reviewText: As a former Marine and father of two sons and grandfather of four I identified with the man, a veteran,  in this movie.  The poignant story is about liberty loving people young and old alike who are heroes. Some heroes die fighting in the service for their country  while others "back home"  are pilloried for their convictions by powerful and intolerant special interest groups.I have felt that the culture is in a mess and my grandchildren are at terrible risk of losing the liberties that this motion picture dramatizes.  The picture is really well produced and well acted with a very positive message that will have the "thought police" and "PC" crowd in an uproar.  No trash or obscenity here.  I liked it as did my family! Go for it! Maybe there is hope for the USA after all.
summary: Thank goodness! A  breath of  fresh air.
Title: Last Ounce of Courage

reviewText: Ok, so let's be real.  All of the agenda pushing aside for a moment.  The acting is for sure is a "B" movie at best, maybe less.  Sets and photography are about like watching a soap opera in some ways.  Probably because of the budget.Now about the theme, it is certainly powerful. It deals with the removal of freedom from a Christian's perspective as well as a Veteran that sees his own son go to war and is killed.  It is very touching.  If you are a veteran, or have family that are currently serving you will need some kleenex during this film.  Since it's centered around Christmas, it will ring home well during that time of year.  As a veteran, a Harley Rider, and a Christian, I loved it, own it on BluRay, and will absolutely give it as a gift.
summary: It's pretty good for a first attempt!

reviewText: In the small American town portrayed in this film, there are unwritten rules that forbid bringing the Bible into the public school and displaying Christmas decorations in the town square. The mayor is inspired by his late son (who died in the first Gulf War) and his grandson to stand up against the enemies of freedom who are denying religious expression to the majority. A few observations:#1 There_is_a social and legal war on Christianity in the United States. If Obama's healthcare mandate isn't religious persecution, then that term has no meaning. However, the obstacles faced by the protagonists in this film don't amount to any sort of persecution. They are the products of some evangelical's overactive imagination.No one is forbidden to bring a Bible into a public school. And the Supreme Court has ruled that government_can_display Christmas decorations on public property so long as the symbols and decorations of other religions or philosophies are represented as well.Now, I don't like that arrangement; I don't want to see the menorah or the Islamic crescent or the atheist atom set up in equality next to the Cross or the creche. That's sacrilege to me. But we can't ignore the First Amendment, which forbids establishment of religion by government.If, throughout most of American history, a homogeneously Christian country was perfectly comfortable with a government that violated the Constitution by favoring a generic version of Christianity (with a Protestant tinge), then that time has passed, as we now have a new nation. First, we let the Jews in, and the Moslems, Buddhists, Hindus and Confucianists, while tolerating atheists as well, and they all have a great legal case, based on the First Amendment, when they object to Christian favoritism by government. If you don't like that, then you should either abolish the Establishment clause of the First Amendment, or figure out some way to get the Jews, Moslems, et al out of the country.Because a Moslem or Jew has the same rights as any other American citizen, it is quite legally sound to forbid Bible readings at a high school graduation, or a Christmas pageant in grade school. How would you like it if you, as a student in a majority Moslem school, had to listen to someone reciting from the Koran at assembly? We allowed our politicians to foist a multicultural society upon us. Now we have to live with the consequences.In any case, this movie's premise was completely ridiculous. What it amounted to was Christians finding out that they are allowed to express their faith in public. That is not the real problem today. What the filmmakers should have tackled was the real legal persecution of Christians in America, such as Obama forcing the Catholic Church to pay for contraception and abortifacients for its employees, against its beliefs; or how bakers, photographers, etc. are being successfully sued because they didn't want to provide their services for a gay wedding.#2. This movie was bad- really bad. There was a moving scene when the family found out about their son/husband's death in Iraq, but otherwise it was a total failure. The plot was ridiculous and dull, the characterizations shallow and absurd, and the acting completely wooden all around. Why do evangelicals make such bad movies?
Title: Last Ounce of Courage

reviewText: I must think I'm such a critic. I watch a lot of movies and tv programs. I sometimes don't get any further than the first few lines, having to duck obscenities that are really not necessary or the even the way most people speak. But this is an entirely different issue. When I watch movies with a Christian theme, I wonder why most of them leave "Jesus" and His name out of them. There's power in His name! Not much when used in an unworthy manner, except to get a look you probably didn't really want.This movie, which I purchased recently from Amazon.com, had a surprising story line and a heroic ending, resolve was actually accomplished here. For those of you looking for a Christian movie that is not goofy or second to fourth rate, choose this one, you won't be sorry.
summary: Finally! A Christian movie that includes Jesus.
Title: Last Ounce of Courage

reviewText: I have watched this movie 3 times since purchasing it. It seems to be my "go to" movie. Great story. Makes you think.
Title: Last Ounce of Courage

reviewText: I watched this movie, and I started crying.  As a Navy/Marine Corps corpsman, I served to defend this country, and our freedoms.  This movie shows, how we as American citizens, are losing our freedoms, especially at Christmas time.  This CMH recipient, just wants to put Christ, back into Christmas.  This is a fantastic movie.  F.Y.I.  For all vets, watch this movie with someone you love, who can comfort you, if you desire.  You will need them.
Title: Last Ounce of Courage

reviewText: Really speaks to the heart about standing up for our faith in the Lord and our freedoms we take for granted, every day!
Title: Last Ounce of Courage

reviewText: If you are looking for a blockbuster movie, keep looking. If you are looking for a movie that displayed the perfect Christian family, keep looking. This family was not the picture family that attends every Sunday and Wednesday and every small group. They don't read the bible and pray. This family lost their son while he was serving our country. They were distraught and frankly a little lost. Even though the patriarch served honorably, he had even lost some sense of patriotism. He became reminded of what he believed in and finally decided to take a stand for freedom again. This movie is more about reminding us to stand up for the freedoms that are being eroded by the politically correct, than it is about Christianity. But the message is a heartwarming one. Lets remember this nation was founded by protestants fleeing religious oppression. There is nowhere left to run, so stand.
Title: Last Ounce of Courage

reviewText: No more season greetings but Merry Christmas. What really is Christmas?Time to wake up and know why we have Christmas and why it is so special to many.
Title: Last Ounce of Courage

reviewText: When I heard that one of my old friends, Marshal Teague  was the star in this movie, I checked Amazon to find it.  The movie is an excellent example of what Christmas really means.  I don't know why the Hallmark Movie Channel does not include this movie in their Christmas Movie Series.
Title: Last Ounce of Courage

reviewText: If you want to see the dangers facing us every day please watch this video. Our troops are our salvation.
Title: Last Ounce of Courage

reviewText: Such an inspiring true story.  Will cause your heart to swell and you will be inspried to "Take a Stand."

reviewText: What a great movie. It makes you want to stand up and be a proud American instead of sitting back and let our rights be taken away from us

reviewText: This is a superb movie! We should all be willing to stand up for freedom, no matter what it requires of us. This movie shows that!
Title: Last Ounce of Courage

reviewText: Wow!!! What a great family movie.This is a movie that must be seen again and again by entire families in order to put things in perspective and to remind everybody where we are coming from. The movie starts and ends we two powerful quotes from Ronald Reagan.It is about a family that lost their son in a recent war and is living a peaceful life without realizing that they have given up their everyday rights and freedom that many soldiers in this great country have died for. Suddenly they realize that slowly they are giving up their rights and they fight all together to restore their right to celebrate Christmas (...for starters). The secular media and ACLU are fighting back (...as is the case today) with a lot of nonsense. While the end is predictable it is a good and positive ending with a great message of hope.After watching the movie I realized that there is a character in the movie that looks like he came straight out of a ZZ Top video that appears in the background in some scenes. I watched the movie again looking for this character and indeed the character was there...At the very end of the movie we get the message. Thank You for being there for us!Five stars because of the last 30 minutes of the movie and because of the powerful message...and Merry Christmas!
summary: Wake up! Stand up for what you believe! You cannot let the enemy take one more inch!
Title: Last Ounce of Courage
